content: It was my senior year. We were in the homecoming game against our biggest rivals, the Rustburg Red Devils. EVERYONE
was at the game. All the work I’d put in since middle school created this opportunity—to start in the homecoming game as
The first three quarters were back and forth—they’d score and then we’d score. By the fourth quarter we were trailing by six,
but we had possession of the ball. Time was running down and we’d gotten just past the fifty yard line. The coach called a 9
ROUTE—it was a long pass to me in the end zone.
In the huddle, I was running through the play in my mind. I could see the ball arcing toward me, coming right into my hands.
Just like my dad taught me—VISION—to bring things into reality, you need to be able to see them clearly before they happen.
As we got to the line, the roar of the crowd intensified. I couldn’t hear the quarterback, so I kept my eye on the ball.
As soon as I saw it move, I bolted downfield. My legs were pumping, my lungs were full. The ball came out of the quarterback's
hand in a perfect spiral. It was just me, the ball, and the end zone.
Our fans were screaming their heads off. Everything felt perfect. After years of practice it was second nature.
But right before I secured the catch, I lost focus. I looked at my hands. The ball slipped right through.
A wave of silence washed over the crowd as the ball hit the ground.
Those words pounded through my brain at the same speed as the blood pumping through my body.
As I looked to the stands I saw people stunned with disbelief. There was still time on the clock but some of the
people at the field level started to walk toward the parking lot.
I dragged myself to the sidelines, expecting to be benched.
When I got to the sideline I walked up to coach. He looked me in the eye. He said, “Get back out there, run the same play.
When I delivered the play to the quarterback my teammates had their doubts, but there was no second guessing. Before we even broke the huddle
I was trying to see the ball into my hands.
We stepped up to the line of scrimmage. I waited for the snap and took off full speed for the end zone. I blew past the cornerback determined to redeem myself.
The quarterback released the ball and it traveled in a perfect arc to the back of the end zone. I could only hear my heartbeat. The ball hit my hands and I held it fast.
From the parking lot, a scout from the University of Richmond heard the crowd roar. He ran back to see what happened. Later,
he offered me a scholarship to play football at the University of Richmond.
“Any kid who has the courage to go back out there and try again is someone we can use on the team,” he said.
But it wasn’t all my own courage or determination that day.
I had a coach and a team who believed in me.
